objectives: Understand and use comparative and superlative forms of adjectives
Use descriptive language to make sentences more interesting

sections.text: Adjectives are words that describe nouns or pronouns. They tell us more about a person, place, animal, or thing. They answer questions like 'What kind?', 'Which one?', 'How many?', or 'Whose?'. Adjectives add color and detail to our sentences, helping us imagine things more clearly. For example, in 'The green fields look beautiful', 'green' and 'beautiful' are adjectives.

examples.label: What kind? (Color)
examples.value: The red flower.

examples.label: What kind? (Size)
examples.value: A big house.

examples.label: What kind? (Quality)
examples.value: A kind boy.

examples.label: How many?
examples.value: Three mangoes.

examples.label: Which one?
examples.value: This book.

examples.label: Whose?
examples.value: My pen.

examples.label: Describing a place
examples.value: Our village has clean water.

examples.label: Describing a person
examples.value: She is a hard-working farmer.

examples.label: Describing an animal
examples.value: The lazy buffalo is sleeping.

examples.label: Describing an object
examples.value: The old well needs repair.

examples.label: Describing a feeling
examples.value: He felt happy today.

examples.label: Describing a sound
examples.value: The loud thunder scared us.

examples.label: Describing a smell
examples.value: The sweet smell of jasmine flowers.

examples.label: Describing a texture
examples.value: The rough ground made walking difficult.

examples.label: Describing a taste
examples.value: The sour lemon made my face pucker.

examples.label: Describing a state
examples.value: The quiet night was peaceful.

usage_examples: Adjectives make sentences interesting.
They describe nouns.
They tell us more details.
Use them to paint a picture with words.
Every noun can have an adjective.

sections.text: Adjectives usually come in two main positions: before the noun they describe, or after 'be' verbs (is, am, are, was, were) or other linking verbs (like seem, feel, look).

examples.label: Before the noun
examples.value: A tall tree is in the field.

examples.label: Before the noun
examples.value: She held a heavy basket.

examples.label: After 'be' verb
examples.value: The tree is tall.

examples.label: After 'be' verb
examples.value: The basket is heavy.

examples.label: Before the noun
examples.value: We saw a beautiful bird.

examples.label: After 'be' verb
examples.value: The bird is beautiful.

examples.label: Before the noun
examples.value: The smart student answered the question.

examples.label: After linking verb 'seem'
examples.value: The student seemed smart.

examples.label: Before the noun
examples.value: The old woman told a long story.

examples.label: After 'be' verb
examples.value: The story was long.

examples.label: Before the noun
examples.value: We drank clean water from the well.

examples.label: After 'be' verb
examples.value: The water from the well is clean.

examples.label: Before the noun
examples.value: A peaceful village is a joy to live in.

examples.label: After linking verb 'feel'
examples.value: The atmosphere felt peaceful.

usage_examples: Place adjectives before the thing they describe.
Or use them after 'is', 'are', 'was', 'were'.
He is a kind person.
The person is kind.
The blue sky is above us.

sections.text: A descriptive adjective is a word that modifies a noun or pronoun by describing its quality or state. [18] These are the most common types of adjectives and they add detail and imagery timages/intermediate/module-2/lesson-2/po your sentences.

examples.label: Describing quality
examples.value: The farmer is a hardworking man.

examples.label: Describing size
examples.value: A small stream flows through the village.

examples.label: Describing color
examples.value: The ripe mangoes are yellow.

examples.label: Describing shape
examples.value: She sat on a round stone.

examples.label: Describing taste
examples.value: The food was delicious.

examples.label: Describing feeling
examples.value: The happy children played in the rain.

usage_examples: A clever fox outsmarted the dog.
The tall tree provides shade.
She wore a beautiful dress.
He told a funny story.

sections.text: Quantitative adjectives describe the quantity of a noun or pronoun, answering the questions 'how much' or 'how many'. [26] This can be a specific number or a general amount. [9]

examples.label: How many (specific)
examples.value: There are seven days in a week.

examples.label: How many (general)
examples.value: Many people attended the village fair.

examples.label: How much (uncountable)
examples.value: There is little water in the pot.

examples.label: How much (uncountable)
examples.value: He has enough knowledge to fix the pump.

examples.label: Specific quantity
examples.value: I ate one apple.

examples.label: General quantity
examples.value: She has some rice.

usage_examples: He has two brothers.
There are few trees on this hill.
I need some sugar for my tea.
She ate the whole plate of food.

sections.text: Demonstrative adjectives are used to point out or indicate a specific noun, answering the question 'which one?'. The main demonstrative adjectives are this, that, these, and those. [6] 'This' and 'these' refer to things nearby, while 'that' and 'those' refer to things farther away. [13, 23]

examples.label: Singular, near
examples.value: This book belongs to me.

examples.label: Plural, near
examples.value: These mangoes are sweet.

examples.label: Singular, far
examples.value: That house is very old.

examples.label: Plural, far
examples.value: Those stars are shining brightly.

examples.label: Pointing out
examples.value: I want that blue shirt.

examples.label: Indicating specific items
examples.value: Please pass me those plates.

usage_examples: This is my village.
That boy is my friend.
I like these flowers.
Those houses are on the other side of the river.

sections.text: A possessive adjective modifies a noun to show ownership or possession. [12] It answers the question 'whose?'. The possessive adjectives are my, your, his, her, its, our, and their. [11]

examples.label: Belonging to 'I'
examples.value: My cow gives a lot of milk.

examples.label: Belonging to 'you'
examples.value: Is this your pen?

examples.label: Belonging to 'he'
examples.value: His field is very large.

examples.label: Belonging to 'she'
examples.value: Her saree is very colorful.

examples.label: Belonging to 'it'
examples.value: The dog wagged its tail.

examples.label: Belonging to 'we'
examples.value: Our village is very clean.

examples.label: Belonging to 'they'
examples.value: Their house has a red roof.

usage_examples: Where is your school?
This is my book.
Our team won the match.
Their crops are ready for harvest.

sections.text: An interrogative adjective is used to modify a noun or pronoun in order to ask a question. [5] The main interrogative adjectives are what, which, and whose. They are always followed by a noun. [7]

examples.label: Asking about something (general)
examples.value: What color is the flower?

examples.label: Asking about a choice
examples.value: Which road should we take?

examples.label: Asking about possession
examples.value: Whose book is this?

examples.label: Asking a question
examples.value: What time is the meeting?

examples.label: Asking about a specific item
examples.value: Which pen do you want?

examples.label: Asking who owns something
examples.value: Whose cattle are grazing in the field?

usage_examples: What advice did he give you?
Which way is the market?
Whose house are we going to?
What is your name?

sections.text: A distributive adjective refers to members of a group individually, rather than collectively. [1] The most common distributive adjectives are each, every, either, and neither. They are always followed by a singular noun and a singular verb. [17]

examples.label: Referring to individuals in a group
examples.value: Each student received a prize.

examples.label: Referring to all members
examples.value: Every house has a water connection.

examples.label: Choice between two
examples.value: You can take either path.

examples.label: None of the two
examples.value: Neither answer is correct.

examples.label: Singling out
examples.value: The teacher spoke to each child.

examples.label: Generalization
examples.value: Every farmer hopes for a good harvest.

usage_examples: Each person must bring their own plate.
Every villager attended the meeting.
Either of the two wells has clean water.
Neither story was true.

sections.text: Comparative adjectives are used to compare two things. They show which of the two has more of a certain quality. We usually add '-er' to short adjectives (like 'tall' becomes 'taller') or use 'more' before longer adjectives (like 'beautiful' becomes 'more beautiful'). We often use 'than' after the comparative adjective.

examples.label: Short adjective (+er)
examples.value: Ram is taller than Shyam.

examples.label: Short adjective (+er)
examples.value: This tree is older than that one.

examples.label: Long adjective (more + adj)
examples.value: The city is more crowded than the village.

examples.label: Irregular (good -> better)
examples.value: Today's weather is better than yesterday's.

examples.label: Irregular (bad -> worse)
examples.value: The old well water is worse than the new well water.

examples.label: Short adjective (+er)
examples.value: The river is wider than the stream.

examples.label: Short adjective (+er)
examples.value: My bag is heavier than your bag.

examples.label: Long adjective (more + adj)
examples.value: This story is more interesting than the last one.

examples.label: Irregular (far -> farther/further)
examples.value: The market is farther from here than the school.

examples.label: Short adjective (+er)
examples.value: The new house is bigger than our old hut.

examples.label: Short adjective (+er)
examples.value: My younger brother is faster than me.

examples.label: Long adjective (more + adj)
examples.value: Learning English is more important for jobs now.

examples.label: Short adjective (+er), changes y to i
examples.value: The road is dustier in summer.

examples.label: Short adjective (+er), double consonant
examples.value: The mud is wetter today after the rain.

examples.label: Long adjective (more + adj)
examples.value: The crops are more healthy this year.

usage_examples: My cow is bigger than his cow.
This path is shorter than that one.
Life in the village is more peaceful than in the city.
She is smarter than her classmates.
The old tractor is slower than the new one.

sections.text: Superlative adjectives are used to compare three or more things. They show which one has the most of a certain quality, or is the highest in a group. We usually add '-est' to short adjectives (like 'tall' becomes 'tallest') or use 'most' before longer adjectives (like 'beautiful' becomes 'most beautiful'). We almost always use 'the' before the superlative adjective.

examples.label: Short adjective (+est)
examples.value: Ram is the tallest boy in the class.

examples.label: Short adjective (+est)
examples.value: Mount Everest is the highest mountain.

examples.label: Long adjective (most + adj)
examples.value: She is the most intelligent student in the school.

examples.label: Irregular (good -> best)
examples.value: This is the best movie I have seen.

examples.label: Irregular (bad -> worst)
examples.value: That was the worst flood in our village history.

examples.label: Short adjective (+est)
examples.value: The banyan tree is the oldest tree in the village.

examples.label: Short adjective (+est)
examples.value: My small hut is the warmest place in winter.

examples.label: Long adjective (most + adj)
examples.value: The sunrise over the fields is the most beautiful sight.

examples.label: Short adjective (+est)
examples.value: He is the strongest farmer in our area.

examples.label: Short adjective (+est), changes y to i
examples.value: This is the easiest lesson to learn.

examples.label: Long adjective (most + adj)
examples.value: Cleaning the village pond was the most important task.

examples.label: Short adjective (+est), double consonant
examples.value: The biggest fish was caught in the river today.

examples.label: Irregular (little -> least)
examples.value: He has the least amount of water left.

examples.label: Short adjective (+est)
examples.value: The children are the happiest when they play together.

examples.label: Long adjective (most + adj)
examples.value: Learning about farming is the most practical skill for villagers.

usage_examples: He is the smartest boy in our class.
This is the fastest animal in the jungle.
The school has the most helpful teachers.
It was the happiest day of my life.
The Ganges is one of the longest rivers.
